text: Draft. Crystal clear yellow color, white head with spiderweb lacing. Aroma of citrus and black pepper. Taste is lightly bitter citrus, subtle pine, clean finish. Decent.

Pours a clear, thin, yellow with a full white head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is weak. From what I can gather, its floral, with wheat and bread. Happily, things get more exciting upon sipping. There is a fair amount of bitterness here. Crisp and clean, its grassy and slightly floral. Cereal, wheat, a slight lemon, and a bit of honey. Very short cereal aftertaste. This is light to medium in body, with a smooth texture, and average in carbonation. Kind of refreshing actually. Its nothing out of this world, but it will do the trick.

Tap at Pour House. Brilliantly clear light yellow color. White foamy head. Fairly light aroma. Low biscuit malt, no hops, low citrus esters. Flavor is moderate-low biscuit malt, dry spicy hops-low. Fair bitterness through the finish. Green apple flavor on the finish. Crisp. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Clear pale gold in color poured with a thin white head that quickly dissipated. Malty farmhouse aroma - wet grass. Very light bodied. Clean finish.

12 ounce bottle from Woodmans in Rockford, IL, sampled at around cellar temp from a Zywiec glass. Huge fluffy large-bubbled gout of foam tops the very pale gold bubbling body, decaying slowly...fresh noble hop nose, with dry straw and new-mown hay, clover and lovely lightly honeyd malts....oh my this is good stuff when it hits the tongue, initially fairly sweet but the sugar fades rapidly and is replaced by a good solid bready, doughy body with some real heft, though it maintains a very light sweet character throughout...finish is moderately dry, long, and with some light herbal hoppy notes....body full, carbonation moderate. Really good stuff; I think these guys are giving some of the better Wisconsin brewers a run for their money on the German styles.
12 oz bottle pours golden with a white head. Aroma and taste is bready, grain and citrus,
Bottle. Pours clear pale golden, medium creamy white head, nice lacing. Aroma is Bready, grass, grain, citrus. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter. Light body.
A bit on the heavier side for the style. The flavor is good and easy. A simple beer on a hot day in Chicago.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2016 Pretty good lager. Ill come back with more description later when I have a minute

Lightly hazed, very light straw color. Fluffy white head with a nice clinging of lace. Orange zest and a hint of smoky wheat in the aromas. Smells a bit more like a wit. Light orange citrus in the start. Very light malt and flour in the middle. Slight medicinal hints. I guess when there is not much depth of flavor its easier to find faults. Not a crisp kolsch for me. 3/10

Keg at Links Taproom - Chicago. Pours clear yellow with a creamy, white head. The nose holds crispy cereal, straw, hay. Light sweet flavour with crispy biscuits, more hay, hints of lemon, cereal. Light bodied with average carbonation. Clean and crisp on the finish, with brisk cereal, fresh biscuit. Very solid lager.

This pours a clear, light yellow color with just a slight head. The aroma is grainy and slightly yeasty like you expect from a Kolsch style brew. The taste is decent and grainy for the style. Its light and easy drink with a clean, refreshing finish. Pretty decent beer for the style!

Yellow beer out of the bottle with a short white head. Nose of lemon and something liked overcooked vegetables. Crackers, lemon cookies, yeasty bread dough with some some berry sweetness. Okay kolsch.
On tap at First Draft. Light pour with a big white head. Aroma is grainy and almost fruity. Taste is still a little fruity with lots of nice bread. Good finish.

So few beers take me back to how wonderful I think I remember them from the 1970s, but Metros Kränkshaft is definitely among them. It even has the carbonation right. A lightly grassy scent with hints of lemon give way to a sweet taste and a finish that is just the slightest bit bitter. A super summer beer that I enjoyed from a bottle.

12 ounce bottle. Just a little white in this golden beer. A noisy fizzy white head dies quickly. So little aroma. Some gentle honey and fruit. That is tasted and the flavor is also light. Gentle fruity and spicy hops. A little more honey is tasted than is in the nose. Some Noble hop notes. Pale malts. This is just an ok Kolsch.

Bottle - good size foamy head, pale yellow color, sweet corn/malty aroma and flavor, mild earthy hop balance, OK overall 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Straw gold. Nose of honeycomb and light citrus hops. Flavor is more honeycomb with herbal citrus bitterness and light mineral quality.

Bottle at home. Clear golden with a huge fluffy white head. Aroma of floral hops and lemon. Sweet corny malt undertones. Bright dry finish with lemon and grass and an un - kolsh - like chemically turpentine note.

Look: pours a pale straw. Bright white head. Extremely clear. 
Smell: Apple skin. Champagne. Sweet malt. 
Taste: tastes almost like a lager. Very malty. Champagne. 
Feel: very crisp finish. Medium high carbonation. Very smooth finish. 
Overall: ok beer. Very European flavor and feel. 
First drank home 4/12/15
Vintage:
Draft sampled at Olympic. From notes. Very light, refreshing and easy drinking. Some nice citrus notes.
Straw yellow pour with a white head. Aroma is malt, little wheat. Tasty, refreshing sweet malt.
Rated based on notes taken on 17 Mar 2012 -- I think this is a great example of a Kolsch. Very refreshing, nice malt flavor, super sessionable.

On tap poured into a shaker. Aromas of bread crust, lemon zest, and a light pine strike the nose. Its a crystal clear pale yellow color with a frothy, soft, dense white head. A thick, dense ring is retained with a light dust surface. Lots of sheet and webby lace is left behind. The taste is a medium sweet and light bitter. The oily textured, light body beer had a soft, soapy carbonation. Citrus sweet some pine, and bread flavors finish the drink. Its crisp and clean with a light toast and citrus aftertaste.

Draft. Pale, straw color. Thin, dense head; substantial lacing. No string aroma. Light flavor with a little hop presence. Medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear yellow pour with a white head. It has a lightly fruity, floral hop aroma. The light body has a smooth texture with lively carbonation. The taste is sweet with a quick, clean finish.

Bottle from the Southloop Binny's served in a footed pilsner glass. Brewed with Santiam hops it pours a light gold with great foamy lacing. Sweet bready vanilla bun aroma. A slightly rough mouthfeel and the taste is sweet fruity vanilla with some butteriness. Alright it is a refreshing beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location: Draft at the Berghoff, 6/2/14


Aroma: The nose is fairly light, some grainy notes, bread, and a bit of fruit

Appearance: It pours a cloudy golden color with a decent sized white head and light lace

Flavor: The flavor is much the same, grainy malts, lightly sweet, fruit, etc.

Palate: The body is light-medium, it has an okay mouthfeel, and solid drinkability

Overall Impression: 
I wasnt overly impressed by this beer. I mean it isnt a bad one or anything, just not all that exciting. You could session this, but you could also probably find a better beer to session.

Light bready malt aroma, with a hint of fruit. Pours a slightly hazy pale straw with a large white head. Slightly sweet flavor, with a touch of bread notes and a hint of apple notes in the finish. Not quite as crisp as I generally prefer my Kolsches. Its a middle of the road Kolsch, nothing really flawed, but nothing outstanding.

スッキリ飲み 
でも味には深&

Straw yellow on color... Big pineapple, fruity potpourri nose... Flavor is light crisp, notes of golden malts, pineapple, slightly bitter finish... Solid

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Nice amber color; Light to medium body; Aroma of malt, grain/hay, & some hops; Flavor of slight sweet malt, grain, hops, and some fruit/citrus; Not too bad.

12oz bottle 1/10/14 (Trader Joes Naperville)-40° in Lager Glass-Pours a clear light golden with a small white ring for a head. Aroma of malt, grains, and hops. Taste of the same along with more sweetness. This light bodied brew was actually pretty decent as I am not usually a fan of this style.

Draft at Ginos East, 2013 ratings catch up -- this was my third choice as the other two beers were sold out. By the time the beer made it to the table, the head was gone, if there was one to begin with. Hazy yellow color. Hops and grass were more noticeable than the wheat aroma. Sweet taste up front and finished with hop bitterness, a bit thin, but had lots of carbonation.
I was quite impressed with this lighter offering. Had good sweetness to it. Lots of cereal notes. But not deadening at all. Very spry. I want to try the other variations now.

On tap. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a sudsy, small white head. The aroma is pale malt, sweet with a mild vinous character, along with a bit of butterscotch. Flavor is fairly sweet, but theres a nice grassy noble hop bite in the finish. Lighter bodied with a fairly modest carbonation level.
Aroma: light, fresh, malt and hops Appearance: golden Taste: moderate sweet and bitter palate: medium Overal
Bottle. Poured light yellow with bright white head. Aroma of sweet malts. Quite smooth slightly bitter.
Bottle.  This beer seems to have something for everybody.  Sweetness, bitterness, and every other ness.  Decent.

Great color beer showing a nice hazy gold. Very good beer to enjoy a nice dinner with. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy unfiltered yellow, huge long lasting head, lots of lacing. Sour wheat, citrusy. Palate slightly watery, light malt, above average carbonation. Decent. Local brewer, so will have to pay a visit, next time out on town.
Draft at Norse bar. PAle golden color, pleasant malt and hops, everything a koelsch should be.

Pours a clear yellow-gold with a big frothy white head. Aroma is dominated by hops: floral and grassy notes stand out the most. Taste is mildly sweet transitioning to sour and a sweet-bitter finish at the end. Mouthfeel is medium with lively carbonation. Lots of lacing on the glass. Overall really refreshing and enjoyable. Again, I am not well versed in lagers and the styles within the lager classification, so I dont have much context for rating or comparing this to other beers of its style.
Aroma is yeast, very slight citrus and perfumed.  The flavor is light citrus, grainy malts, slight sweetness and a medium tart finish.

12 oz. bottle pours a slightly hazy light yellow color with small white head and good lacing.  Aroma is full of wheat bread, yeast, grass, and a bit of fruity hops. Taste is neither sweet nor sour, with a short, slightly dry finish.  Body is light with a crisp mouthfeel and not too much carbonation.  Very refreshing and easily drinkable.  Ive never enjoyed a Kolsch as much as this one.  If I didnt know it was from Chicago, I would have guessed it was from Köln
Bottle from Binnys via SHERM1016...thanks!  Pours a bright yellow with crisp taste...mild malty taste with touch of hops at end.  Tasty.

12oz bottle from Binnys Lakeview.  Pours a clear, bright yellow color with a big white head.  Aroma is light, bready, cereal.  A little light on the palate with average carbonation.  Flavor is sweet, cereal, grassy hops, a little bread, with a light bitter finish.  Very tasty.

This is a perfect lawnmower beer. Its too bad Im drinking this while looking out at my snowy lawn in December.  I bought this in late August so the hops may be aging, but its still pretty good.  Huge citrus, weak bodied, sort of sour at the end.  Bought this at Binnys in Chicago with Dave in 2012.
Draft at burger bar. Not much aroma.  Good smooth taste. Wheat an German beer taste I guess. Liked it for the style
Golden. White head. Stalky aroma. Grassy flavor with a lot of wheat malt. Very sessionable. Good and balanced. The strong wheat flavor is a bit of a turnoff but its still so balanced its good.

12 oz. bottle served in a plastic cup at the Cubs vs. Sox game.

A: Pours a clear golden yellow with a fluffy, long lasting white head forming on the pour. It leaves some sticky sheets of lace behind as I drink.

S: Pretty standard. Lagery yeast with a clear, crisp hop profile. Grassy and slightly malty as well.

T: The taste is a step up as this has a more fruity hop profile than the nose. The finish is nice and clean with a pale malt body.

M: Light bodied, very refreshing with a nice ample carbonation.

O: Well rounded with a good taste and high drinkability. What more could you ask for at a ball park.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 06-28-2012
Mild, grassy aroma.  Pale yellow in color.  Strong, sweet malt flavor up front...finishes like a pilsner but with smoother taste. Gets better as you continue.....solid.

Just an excellent rendition of the Kolsch style.  Hats off to Metropolitan for mastering such a difficult style to master.

Sehr gut!

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2012 12 ounce bottle.  Kolsch is a new style for me and its a strange breed.  I like this one though.  I was impressed by the absolutely clear gold appearance, but it still held an unabashed taste that reminded me of apples and bananas.  Its not cider-like though.  The smell fits in line with the taste.  Overall its really good stuff, lively palate feel and warm on the tongue.

12oz bottle. Rating #72. Clear light yellow pour with a nice white head tgat left a decent amount of lacing. Straw and light grass aroma, very clean with a light sweetness. Mild flavor, more straw and clean malts, picking up tge same metal taste as the alt, it does disappear as it warms so it doesnt detract from the beer overall, just the initial 2 or 3 sips. (2440)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text:
Bottle from trade as an extra. Really nicely made Kolsch, but I'm still partial to the Pyramid version (Curve Ball). Still, this one has a solid palate and is very refreshing and crisp. Nice beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at Smoke Daddys. Pours a clear pale gold with a white head that dissipates to the edges slowly. Aroma has a crisp light grain note with a hint of grassiness and light citrus. Flavor has a good amount of sweet grain with a light grassiness and a hint of sweet citrus in the finish.

Bottle at home - thanks to Baron - Shared with Mette. Clear yellow - white head. Bread, lots of white bread, nice clean pilsner malty, grainy, egg, grassy, herbal hoppy notes, lovely clean and perfect !!!

Pours a hazy off colored rusty gold. Nose is grainy and slightly metallic. Taste is grainy mildly bitter  and not as watery as a typical lager. Finish is sweet, nothing special.....buts its the style, and would take this over any premium lager anytime. Quaff Score 6 / 10
Pours golden yellow with a white head and aroma of metal and grains. Taste is sweet, of grains, toasty malt, and some hops with a dry finish. Not much flavor in this brew, nothing special.

Bottle. Poured a pale lemon with a one-finger white head that quickly dissipated. Smell is sweet corn, grain, DMS, and light lemon. Taste is crisp and refreshing with flavors of corn, grain, light hops, and lemon with a lightly bitter finish. Light body with crisp carbonation. Great for a hot summer day.

Bottle and served in a pint glass: Pours a clean straw hue with a fizzy but lasting head and had spotty lace. The aroma has notes of pale grain, some wheat and white bread dough, hint of lemongrass and some light hop bitterness. Just a hint of "corny" DMS, not all that noticeable however. The taste is clean pale grains and a nice light handed noble hop finish. Slight acidity lemon and herbal twang. A bit heavier than both the Kolsch biers I had before it, I think that is the wheat adding body and mouth feel. For the genre, the mouth feel is way above average. Overall, color me surprised for I expected this to be the least favorite of the three (Shorts 45 and Schlafly Kolsch) but it ended up being my favorite... Note, I have had this once before but that was clearly a skunked bottle, so glad this one was not.

Pale blonde pour.  Single finger head.  Aroma of hops and grain.  Medium mouth.  Taste is light and pleasant.  A little grain in there with a great clean hop finish.  Well crafted, easy drinking, nothing overly special.

Bottle.  Honey, barley malt and hay aroma.  Pale yellow color with moderate head.  Mildly sweet barley malt and lightly bitter herbal hops flavor. Nice body.  Hoppy for a Koelsch - pretty good though.

Originally reviewed: 2/22/11. 12oz bottle poured into a stange glass. Pours a very cloudy yellow/gold. A small white head caps it off right away, but then dissipates quickly. Lots of sticky lace left behind. The nose is fresh with aromas of grass clippings, lemon-lime, spring, floral tones. 

The body is crisp and clean. Carbonation level spritzes it up, without fizzing the mouth up. Lots of lemon tartness, mild hop presence, slight earthy quality. This is a splendid "tame" beer. Perfect for the warmer months, but just fine any other time. Tasty, refreshing beer. Recommend.
On draft pour.  Golden yellowish color with a decent head.  A little grainy with a sweet finish.  Crushable.
Very sweet (not lambic sweet), like miller lite with honey? Not a favorite!

Pours a very pale color, lightly hazy, with a big billowy white head that leaves some lacing on the glass. 

The aroma is bread dough and light lemon zest with a mild peppery character. 

The flavor is clean and nicely bitter the finish is a little sweet but this is pretty well balanced out by the herbal character of the beer. Ive had Kolsh imported from Germany with more hop character than this but the hop character in this beer is still very nice just not specifically dominant. There is a very clean lemony citrus flavor to this beer that is very nice as well. 

Very enjoyable.

Draft at Empty Bottle.  Hazy yellow tan, thin oily head.  Really smooth and creamy, fresh and well done.  Doughy, soft on the palate.  The unfiltered aspect of the beer really adds dimension.  Simple, light body.  Some orange tones.  A hard style to nail down but this comes close.  A great session beer, thirst quenching and sublime.
Bottle.  Pours gold with a white head.  Aroma of grass, bread.  Decent flavor, solid Kolsch.

Pours pale clear gold with visible streams of effervescence that replenish a head that stays for the whole glass.  Aroma is grassy, clean malt.  Taste is buttered bread, grass, and some minor fruitiness.  Body is light to medium, active carbonation, dry clean bready finish.  Overall, fabulous.  These guys are really killing it-- havent had a bad one from them yet.
Pours clear golden with a small white head and minimal lacing. Fruity nectar and bright floral notes comprise the aroma. Soft mouthfeel with nice grainy profile enhanced with light tartness.
Not my favorite style to be certain, but this is a very refreshing beer. I enjoy this beer from time to time- usually served fresh from the fridge either in the bottle or in a pint glass.

Carnivale, Chicago bottle ($6): Pours a golden color without much in the way of head. Aroma is very nice for a kolsch. dry German hops are very much present. Taste is very well-balanced. Hops are there in good measure and blend with the bready malts. In short, this is what a kolsch should taste like. Tasted great with the food at Carnivale.

Pours a clear golden with a sudsy white foamy head. Lightly nutty aroma, sweet malty, a bit creamy full, some vanilla. Flavor is a bit chalky and yeasty, seemingly wheaty, touch of honey, fairly dry. Crisp body, a bit gritty, smaller soda carbonation.

GTMW. Poured clear golden color with an average frothy white head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate balanced malt and floral hop aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Solid drinkable beer and good for style.

On tap at GTMW - straw yellow pour with a thin white head. Smell is corn and light malt. Light floral hops. Taste is more yeasty and macro-ish, with a bit of loght hops on the finish. OK carb, with a light body.

12 oz bottle. This Kolsch was certainly not bad, but slightly missed its mark for me. There was a bit too much of a quality, which the best description I have for it is: mineral and rye.  The aroma is quite buttery and light, not so unlike a bag of popcorn, but with estery fruit, lemony grass, and rye toast as well. It poured with a fluffy layer of creamy white head that mostly dissipates, fair carbonation, a slightly watery appearing body, and a crisp lemon yellow color. The body is decently balanced, light, but not watery, though not as quenching as it could be. Getting passed the hint of metallic minerals and off-rye grain up front, some decent notes come through after. Buttered white toast, light citrus, some herb, estery melon, and nutty grains with minor squash fruit in the finish. An interesting beer, though not quite my thing.

12 oz bottle.  Appearance is golden yellow, straw color.  Aroma is wheat and some citrus and lemongrass.  Taste is corresponding with wheat and slight citrus coming through.  The palate is the most disappointing part of this brew - medium-bodied and slightly viscous giving it a bit of an unpleasant mouthfeel.  In this respect the beer is completely divergent from the Kölsch style which typically has a very clean and crisp body.

Pale yellow with a sudsy white head that lasts and blankets the top, leaving thick rings of lacing. Sweet aroma of grains, dough, and light citrus. Flavor is mostly sweet but finishes clean. Light body with very soft carbonation. Decent summer beer.

Ordered this bottle from West Lakeview Liquors. Served in a pilsner glass.

Pour brings a slightly-dark golden color; its a bit too dark for the style. White head that lasts for a short while before falling without too much lacing. Very thin collar throughout. Nose is bready and faintly pleasant with a fairly-large amount of fruity notes for the style. The taste is more toward the bready end of the spectrum with a bit of fruit and a very mild bitterness in the finish. Body is light but more toward medium than it should be. Carbonation is a tad bit low. Drinks pretty well overall, but is just good, not great.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-03-2011
Went on a brewery tour a while back. Really nice people and a really good beer. I would highly recommend a nice smooth beer, especially for socializing.

The beer is a super clear straw with about a finger and half of white head. Decent retention, ok lacing. 

The aroma us super light, hardly gives off anything at all.

The taste is super light as well, all water pretty much. There is a light skunk finish.

The feel is super light.

The beer is very easy to drink, but its like drinking a glass of water, why would you want to drink it?

12 oz bottle poured into pint glass.  Pours a hazy light golden color with a medium head.  Light body.  Very crisp and refreshing.  Taste a biscuit/dough like presence.  Easy to drink and makes an excellent summer brew

Pours a hazy light golden body with a white head that fleets quickly.
Aromatically grape notes, grain, light grains.  Biscuit and herbal fruit tones.  Apple skins, apple juice notes.  Bland body very grain y a hint of fruit almost lime like zest but probably more just the fleeting carbonation upon combination with salvatory carbonic acid.  A light metallic note, almost tin in nature.

POurs a straw pale yellow with nice notes of light spice on the nose.  A good head develops a nice mouthfeel that is light but yet fulfilling of generous notes of spice, malt, and light hop.  A good go to beer.

12oz bottle pours a very light Yellow with a finger of head.  very light  easy to drink.  would make an excellent summer beer.   Has a light lemony taste and around and finishes a little sweet with a hint of honey.  Dont drink a ton of this style but this must be near the top of the class

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2011 Re-rate: 12oz bottle. Pours a crystal clear, straw-yellow colored body with a finger-width, frothy, white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma has a good amount of lemony florals with a lightly sweetened honey-pale malt with some grain. Just a touch of herbal hops with some apple as well. Flavor is similar. Lightly sweetened, pale, honey malts up front with some grains. More lemon and a good amount of florals giving off some pear and white grapefruit. Finishes clean and dry with a touch of honey-wheat and a very light grassy bitterness. Medium length aftertaste following a light, crisp, smooth body and a moderate carbonation. Overall, a solid Kölsch. Very easy drinking and enjoyable. Not crazy complex, but a lightly sweetened, honey-grain maltiness is balanced well with a floral, lemony crispness. Bumping this up a point. 7,3,7,3,13. Original rating 1/2/2011: On tap at Sheffields. Pours a clouded, pale golden colored body with a finger-width, frothy, off-white head that dissipates quickly and leaves a moderate lacing. Aroma is florals and a lightly sweetened grainy, caramel maltiness. A touch of citrusy lemon and honey. Flavor is similar. Sweeter, honey, pale malts with a light grainy caramel. A light lemon-citrus-grass before this finishes with a clean, light, dry bitterness that leaves a medium length aftertaste. Light, crisp body and moderate carbonation. Overall, an easy drinking Kölsch. Pleasant, light grassy citrus makes this enjoyable enough. Not bad. 6,3,6,3,13=3.2

There is a slight skunkiness to the aroma behind the strong citrus influence. The head was snowy white, which never fades entirely. The brew is a pale yellow, similar to ginger ale. It tastes lemony, quite light and refreshing. It is quite carbonized, not adversely affecting the palate. The aftertaste is lightly lemony, quick to fade. A pleasant light beer.

12 oz bottle @ ODonovans while watching the Bears clinch the NFC North on a Monday night. Clear yellow color with a white head. Yeasty and malty aroma with a hint of lemon citrus. Light malty flavor witha light floral taste. Dry crisp bitter finish.
Cloudy pour. Corn/metallic nose. No malt/hops in the flavor. Goes down extra smooth and is a good thirst quencher.

Pours golden, looks like a kolsch, nice crisp aroma and taste - lots of flavors going on in this, maybe  a few too many.  I usually dont acre for Kolsch and this example is not really swaying me.  for a lighter style beer from this brewery, get yourself a Flywheel, it is MUCH better.

[Tap] Pours a bright golden color with about an inch worth of white head. The aroma is of cereal grain and fresh light hops. Sweet and grassy taste is well balanced. Lingering citrus notes. Very good in body for the style. Refreshing and clean tasting, which is not always the case with these styles. This would be a great crossover beer for the average consumer.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 Bottle at Shoeless Joes in Chicago. Pours a slightly cloudy pale golden color with a thin white head that recedes steadily. Short strings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of fruit and honey. Light body with flavors of citrus, honey and malt. Mild hops in the background. The finish is lemony with a lingering fruity aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

Draught at small bar division. Clear gold with a very nice creamy white head that leaves great lacing. A perfectly presented pint. Sweet malty aroma with some floral and spicy honey. Hops are relatively subtle on the nose but add a nice touch. Sweet and malty with very light banana and peach. Lightly bitter through the finish with a nice spicy hop touch. Medium-light body and tight carbonation. Very well balanced and fermented perfectly. A great kolsch.

bottle from alewatcher.   Thanks!    pours a clear creamy yellow with a big soapy white head.   aroma of fresh herbs, fresh cut grass, some cereal and biscuity malts.   some light perfume and bubblegum backdrop. fresh herb, and grass forward.  really nice.   flavor is  biscuity sweet corn.  could be a bit drier.    tasty.   great beer.

aroma is clean malted cereal grain, light peach pokes through.  appearance is highly polished gold, film head, zero lacing, good carb.  flavor is excellent fruitiness: peach, pear.  mouthfeel is borderline gritty, otherwise fast moving and slick.  nice counterpoint to their alt.

Thanks to stace for the bottle.  

I cant say that Ive had all that many different examples of this style, but this is a good beer, refreshing and summery.  It pours a somewhat hazy pale yellow, somewhere between maize and madder yellow.  Head is sudsy, relatively small and white.  The aroma is pale malt-sweet with a mild vinous character.  Id prefer a bit more grape, but its a minor complaint.  A tiny bit of butterscotch sneaks in as it warms.  Flavor is fairly sweet, but theres a nice grassy noble hop bite in the finish.  This is a refreshing beer that doesnt try to overwhelm you with flavor.  Good for a hot day.  Mouthfeel is light, airy and a touch slick.  Good beer though Im still not entirely won over to the style.
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 I think I like this better than some german Kölsches I have had.  For its style I felt it was quite flavorful.  Serving:Bottle

Nose is light and wheaty, soft grain, a touch of lemon. Pours hazy straw yellow, frothy head and good sticky lace. Wheat, light grain, lemon, and a hint of earth round out the soft flavors of this one. Becomes a little grainier as it warms. Lemony crisp finish.

Tastes like a cider, looks like a ginger ale.  This doesnt seem like beer.  Also, my wife had an allergic reaction to something in the beer.  Im not sure what it was, but she broke out in a full-body rash twice, each the day after having one of these.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2010 Very pale color, small foamy head. Slightly citric hops and a bit of nutty malt in the nose. Slightly tart and delicately flavored. Mouthfeel is a bit slick w/ vigorous carbonation. Finishes w/ a mild earthy bitterness. Really nice light ale. Glad I picked up a sixer.

Draft @ Hackneys, Chicago, IL. Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty grainy aroma. Fruity malty grainy flavor with some hoppy hints. Has a fruity malty grainy finish.

On tap at Brewery tour. Pours clear yellow. Hoppy flavor but is fairly restrained. Tastes a bit wheatey even though I know theres no actual wheat in this beer. Clean finish and very sessionable from a flavor standpoint.

Very good offering from this Chicago lager brewery.  12 oz bottle, pours golden and hazy.  Aroma seems sweet at first, but after a couple of sniffs it reveals the wheat, corn, malt, and a hint of yeast.  Very smooth and refreshing, rather present aftertaste that lingers in a good way.  Tastes similar to how it smells but the wheat and light hops become much more powerful on its way down.  Two thumbs up!

12oz bottle. Pours golden clear with a foamy white head. Lots of carbonation bubbles. Aroma is of malt, corn, wheat, some hops, and grass. Taste is of corn, wheat, and grass. Has a lightly hopped taste to it as well. Biscuity malt backbone evens the beer out. Mouthfeel is light and very carbonated. Lingering taste of grassiness. Very easy drinking, and not too bad of a taste either. I enjoyed it.
Found this one bottled at Binnys in St. Charles, Illinois.  Hazy, light yellow pour with a bubbly white head, grassy citrus nose, mild citrus flavor, mild all around, and very sessionable.

12 oz. bottle. The Krankshaft finally made it our to the burbs, so I can claim all of Metros primary brews. Warm, malty beer smell as soon as I pop the crown. Pours a hazy straw color, with a steady stream of bubbles feeding a slightly fizzy white head. In the glass, theres a slight fruity smell of a warm ferment. Fruit is more prominent in the first sip. A nice biscuity malt body thats easy drinking. Spicy hops (the label now refers not to Tettnang, but Santiam, an American hybrid with Tettnang in its lineage). Stands up well against the more established Goose island Summertime. Taste is fresh and sunny, and goes down easy, even if its just a little gassy afterward.
pours very pale yellow almost like a wit aromas and taste are very light of pale malts and hops but i did like it very much for a rather light style

Bottle.  Pours a slightly hazy pale straw color with just a few whisps of off-white head.  Aroma is very floral and  lightly sweet.  Flavor is a light sweetness upfront with a slightly metallic malt body, finishes with a fruity tartness.  Lively carbonation, light bodied.

The pour on this beer looks as if you just opened up a can of lemonade with an extremely thin white head. You get large aroma of citrus, specifically lemon. The taste was dominated by lemons, but also gave a shot of wheat and honey. Very drinkable beer,  but I would have enjoyed it more if it wasnt 15 degrees out and snowing.
This beer pours deep gold with a fine white head. Flavor is grassy and sweet. The mouthfeel is thicker than many other lagers. Im not as familiar with the Kolsch type, but its not bad.
bottle, slight cloudy broomstraw color, good bright white foam, aroma of hoppy lemons, flavor is a little sweet, white grapejuice and lemonade

12oz bottle from Orland Park Binnys singles rack. Pours clear light golden yellow with foamy white head. Aroma is grainy with some sweet malts. Flavor is grains, banana, vanilla, bready malts, and smidge of grassy hops. Crisp and refreshing. Fizzy carbonation. Good beer for a hot summer day. Unsure why they released it in the fall but this only their 3rd release so oh well.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2010 On tap at The Map Room.  Pours a clear golden with a sudsy white foamy head.  Lightly nutty aroma, sweet malty, a bit creamy full, some vanilla.  Flavor is a bit chalky and yeasty, seemingly wheaty, touch of honey, fairly dry.  Crisp body, a bit gritty, smaller soda carbonation.

Pours a pale golden yellow color with a very slight haze and some lighter clear golden banana yellow notes when held to a light source. Two finger frothy white head that slowly fades into a lasting ring.

Slightly earthy aroma with hints of bready yeast, crisp light fruit notes, mostly apple and banana, as well as some grass, straw and earthy hops.

Surprisingly full bodied for the style and considering how pale it is. Crisp spiciness up front with a nice bit of floral hops followed by a yeasty bready body with hints of pilsner malt and light crisp fruit notes, mostly apple and banana. Also, there is a bit of earthy grass and straw presence that compliment the sweetness of the light fruit and malts as well as the slightly earthy hops. Very easy drinking and flavorful. Recommended.

draft at the maproom. poured slightly hazed and very pale straw color with foamy head. the aroma had a soft earthy quality, grassy sazz hops and big lager yeast smell. the flavor was a bit of a let down, lacking the noble hop character, lots of lager yeast and some sour lemon zest to it. a good example of a kolsch, although when summertime is $20/24pk and this is $10/6pk, I dont see myself drinking this often.

Draft at Sheffields. Pours a slightly hazy yellow with a white head. It smells and feels bigger than a kolsch, Ive had better from Chicago. Nose is malty with light Continental hops. Taste is a bit sweet and rich, distant malt flavors in the background and no hop taste. Decent beer, would drink it a lot but its the third best beer they brew. Still, quality.

I picked this up at Binnys Beverage Depot in Orland Park, Illinois.  It poured an extremely pale yellow body with a tall, firm head and left some spotty lace.  The aroma was light - grainy with a honey sugar sweetness and a touch of fresh grasses.  The flavor was likewise light and has the addition of a lemon twist.  Not a bad warm weather brew.

Pours the palest yellow possible with a bit of chill haze and a nice white creamy head on top. Flowery, yeasty nose with a spritz of lemon. Lightly tart, refreshing lemon flavor with bready notes. Spitzy carbonation, nice mouthfeel.  Another winner by Metropolitan, this blows most attempts at a Kolsch out of the water.

Very pale yellow with big, foamy white head / Yeasty, lemon nose / Light body, creamy with modest carbonation, with good balance and smooth, lightly tart finish / Flavors of bread dough, lemon, and wheat / A delicious, summer session beer.

On draught at the Great Taste of Midwest 2009 in Madison, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-hazy golden yellow colored brew with a thin white head that quickly dissipates, yet leaves behind some spotty lacing. Aroma of light fruit, some golden grain malt, a touch of honey and some flowery hops. Taste is medium bodied, flavors of golden multi-grain, flowery hops and a touch of pear. Finish is golden grain malt with a short lived bitterness that is quite smooth.

Sampled at the GTOM and poured by co-owner Tracy Hurst to a 09 fest glass a light golden hue. The head was a very modest, white foam with some clingy lacing... both hard to note due to the size of the sample and glass and possible lack of good pre-rinsing. The aroma was soft grain as wheat, a touch of sweetness, and some light hints of pear/apple. The flavor mimicked the nose and added a little noble hop and low hop bitterness. Light and quaffable with a subtle dry finish.

Sampled at GTMW 2009 (Madison, WI). Pours a hazy straw yellow that films and laces ok. Aromas are light fruity, fresh apple, with a touch of honey and grain. Initial is light and sessionable, grainy with honey and cereal, fruity apple and pear. Very nice sessionable kolsch that is very flavorful and throws off good fruity qualities. Easily my favorite Metropolitan brew thus far.

GTMW ’08. Poured a slightly hazy golden color with a white head. Not much in the nose except some subdued cereal grain. Light bodied and delicately sweet. Nice fresh cereal grain and yeasty dough flavors. Light and refreshing.
